oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here we have a part of the boat scene we have already seen. Cedar Grove was used as a hospital for the soldiers during the War Between the States, and when we consider that they cooked in this room we wonder that the walls were not blackened by smoke. If the paper on the walls could have talked it could have told us much that we would love to hear. Perhaps some stories the soldiers told one another to while away the lonely hours as they longed for home. My uncle William Scott told one thing that happened in this room. He said my grandmother believed in rearing her children according to the Bible. When one of them was guilty of some misdemeanor, she would take them in the old parlor and talk seriously of the sin they had committed, they would then get down on their knees and she would pray for them and for herself - then she would use the rod. My uncle said he never heard a word of the serious talk or the prayer for he knew what was to follow. However, he must have felt the affect of it all and evidently the prayers of the good mother were answered for he grew up to be a Christian lawyer, and an elder in the Presbyterian Church. We are loathe to leave this old parlor with its associations, but here we are at the door we entered, and we must pass out and close the door behind us and leave all the sweet memories of the past.
